metadata.title: Cubital Tunnel Syndrome
anatomical location body part affected: Ulnar nerve at the medial aspect of elbow (site of compression); ring and little fingers, intrinsic hand muscles, finger flexors, wrist flexors (impacted by nerve compression)
description: Cubital tunnel syndrome (CuTS) is a common peripheral neuropathy, affecting the ulnar nerve (UN). It is due to compression/entrapment, traction, or ischemia at the post-condylar  (also called medial epicondylaror retro-epicondylar)groove  (behind the medial epicondyle) of the elbow(1,2)

CuTS is characterized by paresthesias and motor deficits in the distribution of the UN. Similar symptoms occur with other diagnoses, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, injury at Guyon’s canal, thoracic outlet syndrome, or C8-T1  radiculopathy, which must be ruled out(1,2)

Conservative treatment of patients with CuTS involves rest/activity modification, splinting to limit elbow flexion, progressive hand and wrist strengthening, modalities (as indicated), functional training (as indicated), and education to minimize provoking factors in daily activities and sports. Cortisone injection may be trialed in severe cases
Patients with persistent or recurrent CuTS, or moderate to severe symptoms, are surgical candidates for release or translocation of the UN(2)
Comparative studies of outcomes after different therapy interventions or after conservative versus surgical management are lacking in the literature

ICD-10 codes.G56.20: lesion of ulnar nerve, unspecified upper limb
ICD-10 codes.G56.21: lesion of the ulnar nerve, right upper limb
ICD-10 codes.G56.22: lesion of the ulnar nerve, left upper limb (ICD codes are provided for the readers’ reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement for initial treatment of CuTShas been identified.
presentation signs and symptoms: Intermittent or continuous paresthesias (e.g., “pins and needles,”tingling, numbness) and dull ache that radiates from the medial side of forearm to the 5th digit and ulnar side of 4th digit. Sensory changes intensify with prolonged elbow bending (e.g., holding a phone, sleeping with elbow hyperflexion) or pressure on the medial elbow (1,2)

Explicit pain is less commonly reported than dull ache –Researchers found a negative correlation between medial elbow pain and positive electrodiagnostic testing in a retrospective review of 884 patient charts for patients referred for evaluation of the ulnar nerve at the elbow. The patients had been referred  for electrodiagnostic evaluation based on a clinical suspicion of ulnar neuropathy at the elbow
Sensory deficits in the palmar and dorsal aspects of the 5th digit and ulnar side of the 4th digit. Clumsiness/reduced dexterity related to finger numbness and intrinsic hand muscle involvement (20)

Deformities associated with chronic CuTSinclude(3) –clawing of the 4th and 5th digits due to intrinsic muscle (i.e., ulnar nerve innervated lumbricals) atrophy (while the long finger flexors remain intact) –posturing of the 5th digit in abduction (Wartenberg’s sign) due to weak palmar interosseous muscle being unable to balance the abduction force of the extensor digitiminimi –hyperflexion of thumb when pinching (Froment’s sign) due to weak adductor pollicis muscle being compensated for by flexor pollicis longus

Upper extremity postural changes may be observed (e.g., less shoulder abduction, less elbow flexion, more forearm pronation, and more wrist extension compared to the uninvolved side). These appear to result from the patient avoiding stretch on the affected ulnar nerve
Nocturnal numbness in distribution of ulnar nerve when sleeping with elbow flexed past 90˚

overall contraindications precautions: Avoid increasing tension or pressure on the ulnar nerve with manual techniques (e.g., soft-tissue  mobilization, upper limb tension testing), because overstretching and compression are implicated as etiologic factors(6)
Restrict or modify ADLs, sports, and work activities involving elbow/hand positions and movements that provoke symptoms
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When did symptoms begin? What has been the general progression of the symptoms; i.e., are the symptoms recurrent or persistent? Did the patient delay treatment and present initially with severe symptoms (i.e., with so-called tardy ulnar palsy), suggesting an advanced stage of CuTS? Document whether repetitive activities that can compress or stretch the ulnar nerve were involved. Was there any direct trauma to the elbow?

course of treatment.medical management: Have splinting, activity modification, or medications been trialed?
surgical management: Surgical management: Surgical referral usually follows failed conservative treatment (i.e., refractory symptoms, including decreased dexterity and hand muscle atrophy, or recurrent symptoms). What operative techniques were performed, if any, and when? Surgical treatment techniques include medial epicondylectomy, simple endoscopic decompression, and anterior transposition (subcutaneous, intramuscular, or submuscular).(3)A surgical treatment known as “fascia wrapping” involves subfascial transposition, which wraps the ulnar nerve with fascia to facilitate improvements with nerve gliding.(17)Consensus on the best surgical treatment is lacking.Consultation with the treating physician is best to determine an appropriate surgical plan for the specific clinical scenario (3)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications (e.g., anti-inflammatories)  clinician has prescribed. Are they being taken? Are they effective?
diagnostic tests completed: assess the elbow and rule out possible fracture (2)
identify osteophytes that may be present andcompressing the nerve (1,2)
assess cervical spine if suspicious about cause of neurological symptoms (i.e., whether of central origin)
Blood tests to exclude diabetic neuropathy (1)
Diagnostic ultrasound and MRI to assess the cubital tunnel and to rule out tumors, cysts, and other soft tissue anomalies that might cause compression of ulnar nerve (2)
Authors of a systematic review designed to assess the utility of ultrasound to measure the cross-sectional  area of the
ulnar nerve found that there is a difference in ulnar nerve crosssectional  area between patients with and without CuTS.
They found that asymptomatic patients rarely have a crosssectional  area more than 10mm2; thus that value could be considered a cutoff point for diagnosing CuTS (26)

Electrodiagnostic and electromyographic studies (EMG and nerve conduction study [NCS]) to confirm the diagnosis, assess degree and location of ulnar nerve damage, and monitor course of recovery. Early in the presentation, EMG and NCS maybe normal and should be interpreted based on clinical findings (2)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack, compression elbow sleeve) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Ask about onset of symptoms (sudden or gradual), quality/intensity/duration of pain, effect on daily activities, aggravating factors, and alleviating factors
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Is weakness or incoordination present?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also, document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Does patient sleep with involved elbow flexed more than 90˚? Does patient wake up with increased symptoms?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could be indicative of a need to refer to a physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any known respiratory compromise? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any prior elbow or hand problems, fractures, or surgery? Any neck problems or injury? Any history of other neuropathy?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, renal failure, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic conditions
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Does the patient wear an orthosis or protective sleeve? Do symptoms affect occupational and recreational activities? What involvement of elbow and wrist activities does patient’s job or recreational activities (e.g., sports, playing a musical instrument) require? Is the patient a smoker?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Which work or daily activities contribute to symptoms? Sleep position?
social and occupational history.living environment: Inquire about layout of home. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) A comprehensive review is available on clinical testing techniques for suspected ulnar neuropathy(7)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Evaluate orthosis (e.g., anti-claw  orthosis, elbow extension orthosis) for proper fit. Assess elbow/hand function with orthosis on and off. Are any devices indicated due to lack of hand function?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess dynamic balance reactions, as indicated, if use of affected arm is limitedAssess efficiency of movements during aggravating activities and work simulation. Assess workstation setup, if indicated by occupational risk
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess radial and ulnar pulses at the wrist; capillary filling in hand should be unaffectedAssess whether transfers are limited by weight-bearing  restrictions, if indicated by functional limitations
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess upper extremity posture during gait, as indicated by postural changesAssess accessory motion of ulnar and radiocarpal joints and intercarpal jointsComplete assessment of coordination and muscle tone of the upper –Jebsen-Taylor  Hand Test –9-hole  Peg Test –Purdue Pegboard Test
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manual muscle testing (MMT)finger spread, extension of 4th and 5th digits at metacarpal phalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints; thumb squeeze against base of 2nd digit patient holds sheet of paper between 4th and 5th fingers while examiner pulls on sheet (positive if obviously weak grip) –Use a dynamometer and pinch gauge to measure grip and pinch strength (compare results bilaterally and for sex/age) –Assess and compare strength of wrist flexion;i.e., flexor carpiulnaris (innervated by the ulnar nerve) vs. flexor carpiradialis (innervated by the median nerve) –Weakness in flexion at the distal interphalangeal joint of the 5th digit(15) –General muscle strength assessment(7) -Finger spread – C8, T1, ulnar -Finger extension at MCP and PIP – C7-8,  radial -Grip strength – C7-T1,  median and ulnar -Press thumb against base of index finger – C8, T1, ulnar -Pinch between thumb and fifth digit – C8, T1, median -Flex thumb – C8, median -Extend wrist – C6-8,  radial -Flex wrist – C6-7,  median -Supinate forearm with elbow extended – C5-6, radial -Pronate forearm with elbow extended – C6-7, median -Flex elbow with forearm supinated – C5-6, musculocutaneous -Extend elbow – C6-8,  radial -Shoulder abduction – C5-6,  axillary
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess alignment at elbow and wrist. Complete a general upper body postural assessment as indicated. Evaluate postures that exacerbate or reproduce symptoms
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess using goniometry –Measure active and passive ROM at elbow and wrist joints. Check for subluxation of ulnar nerve from cubital tunnel on passive overpressure in elbow flexion. Compare to uninvolved side –Complete a cervical screen to rule out C8 radiculopathy
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess upper extremity stretch reflexesDetermine whether there are deficits in hand function/dexterity that may impair personal care. Ask patient to demonstrate daily activities that provoke symptoms. Do these activities involve repetitive elbow flexion or increase pressure on palm of hand? –Manual Ability Measure 36 (MAM-36)(21,22)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess sensation (pinprick, light touch, temperature) in distribution of ulnar nerve (i.e., side of hand proximal to 5th digit). Expect positive Tinel’s and compression signs with percussion at cubital tunnel or ulnar nerve tunnel and reduced sensation over the volar aspect of hand
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisAbduction of the little finger with extension of the fingers is associated with severe ulnar nerve injuryDoes static elbow flexion with forearm supinated and wrist neutral at full flexion for 3 minutes provoke symptoms? (1)Does percussion of ulnar nerve at or just proximal to the cubital tunnel reproduce paresthesias? (1) –Note that the elbow flexion test and Tinel’s sign should be interpreted with caution because they were often found falsely positive in asymptomatic individuals without CuTS(8)Inability to actively flex the distal phalanx of 5th digit(15) –Patient-reported  outcomes for upper limb function -Upper Limb Function Scale (ULFS) -Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure (24)  -For more information on the DASH, see Clinical Review…Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder, Hand (DASH) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number T903177

contraindications precautions: Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
Cold may be counterproductive if being used to facilitate muscle relaxation and reduce pain in patients who do not tolerate the modality
Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
Over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
Over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
In an area with infection or bleeding
If a tumor is present in the area
In the area of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
Over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia
Patients who cannot communicate effectively (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier)
other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Avoid overstretching and compression of the ulnar nerve, as indicated by provocation of symptoms during elbow/hand positions and movements in ADLs, sports, and work activities

Electrotherapy contraindications/precautions (in some cases,  when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(9)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Ulnar nerve entrapment/paresthesias and/or weakness in the distribution of the ulnar nerve that reduce hand function; patient education for modification or avoidance of provocative activities; postoperative surgical repair
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Ulnar tunnel syndrome Carpal tunnel syndrome (distinguishing symptoms involve first 3 digits and nocturnal pain) Ulnar nerve contusion/direct trauma Wartenberg’s radial neuritis (sensory only and does not involve 4th or 5th fingers) Cervical radiculitis (main feature is neck pain/trauma) Raynaud’s syndrome (all fingers cold and present with a blue tint) Thoracic outlet syndrome (if symptoms depend on shoulder position) Cervical cord compression/C8 nerve root entrapment (bilateral symptoms) Diabetes polyneuropathy Chronic regional pain syndrome
prognosis: Although quality studies are lacking to assess the efficacy of conservative intervention for CuTS, authors of a systematic review found that in mild or moderate CuTS there is a role for education, activity modification, and/or splinting(10)
Prognosis is generally poor if symptoms recur or persist after surgery(16)

Researchers used a survey methodology to determine surgeons’ preferred treatment of cubital tunnel syndrome. Findings included (11) –Recommendation for continued conservative treatment for intermittent symptoms and normal EMG, even with symptoms lasting longer than 6 months –Open in situ decompression was the preferred surgical intervention with symptomatic EMG-positive  patients without ulnar nerve subluxation
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines To hand surgeon or neurosurgeon as indicated Back to physician for increased symptoms or reduced function
treatment summary: No clinical trials are available to guide physical therapy intervention in patients with CuTS

Treatment usually involves symptom management, activity modification, and forearm and hand strengthening/stretching as prescribed. Splinting may be trialed to limit elbow flexion. Patient education and progressive return to normal activities should also be included(1)

Authors of a systematic review designed to assess conservative treatment for patients with mild to moderate CuTS found clinical improvement with a 6–12  week course of conservative treatment including splinting, patient education, and activity modification (10) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Paresthesias/pain Reduce or resolve symptomsPhysical agents and mechanical modalities _ Trial of iontophoresis or phonophoresis with dexamethasone for pain management as indicated and ordered by physician _ _ Cryotherapy for pain management may also be tried _ _ Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Trial of elbow orthosis in a neutral position (primarily at night); elbow pad/support to decrease pressure on the medial elbow during activities and/or sleeping _ _ Activity modification _ Implement changes to help reduce symptoms associated with provoking activities (e.g., using a headset for telephone)Gradual reduction in symptomsPatient education in use of effective modalities  Wrist/hand weakness Increase strength and prevent atrophyTherapeutic exercises _ Comparative methods of hand/ wrist strengthening exercises have not been reported for CuTS. Consequently, therapeutic strengthening and dexterity exercises should be guided by the evaluation on a case- by-case basis(1,10) _ _ To gently stretch the tissues surrounding theulnar nerve, instruct the patient to depress shoulder, laterally rotate and abduct shoulder, flex elbow, supinate forearm, place wrist in extension, and flex neck laterally away from affected side(1,12) _ _ Electrotherapeutic modalities _ Electric stimulation can be trialed to reduce or prevent atrophy(12)Progress each patient as appropriate and indicatedA home exercise program may be implemented after

maintenance or prevention: Continued avoidance of activities and positions that aggravate symptoms (e.g., pressure on the ulnar nerve, sleeping with flexed elbows, holding a phone for prolonged periods), self-management  of pain
